text: Family Member: The radium since it’s an injection is it IV injection or just a shot? Doctor: It is. No, they put a little IV in and then they kind of push it in over a minute and then you’re good for the month. Now, technically that’s liquid radiation so you’re kind of glowy. Patient: Ah. Okay. Doctor: So, do I advise that you go to the airport or to the Canadian border right after? No. Patient: No, that would not. Doctor: that’s not a good idea, no, no. But, you know, within a matter of like a few days it’s out. Now, its reasonably compared to all the other radiopharmaceuticals, easier to clean up. So, for example, if, and just for the record it’s like a fifteen thousand dollar vial. If you are oops and it lands on the floor, you don’t have to evacuate the building. Actually, what you do is you just put a piece of paper on there and then it’s protected. So, the half-life is really short but because it’s swirling in you as a human and then it stays in your bone which is why it’s only in the bone because it only goes to bone, um you will glow a smidge. So, we don’t want you to have like a newborn held up to you because you still will emit some sort of radiation. Patient: Okay, Alright. Family Member: Just for the first few days? Doctor: Yeah, they’ll give you like a set time. Oh, yeah, yeah, yeah, and same thing, you know, when you go to the bathroom. It’s the same thing because he doesn’t want to nail you just because you’re sitting next to him it shouldn’t be but, you know, for the younger people or people who are more immunocompromised who are older they get at risk for stuff and we say why bother. Family Member: They won’t put a port in him will they? Doctor: No, we shouldn’t have to. We shouldn’t have to. Family Member: Even though when they get him they go to the Docetaxal?

text: Healthcare Professional: You want to go - Well maybe you should go down there and then you can come back up and get your treatment. Doctor: Yeah, maybe you can go, yeah, okay. Healthcare Professional: Yeah, that way you don’t miss your appointment down there. Doctor: Yeah that makes sense, while they’re preparing the treatment. Family Member: Right. Patient: I can tell him thanks for buying her a new car. Doctor: He didn’t buy it. Healthcare Professional: She probably bought it (chuckles) Patient: Oh it’s you – it’s your it’s everybodies - it’s both your monies; it’s not just - Doctor: No, no, he is just, yeah. No, but he’s really trying to drive it as much as he can right now. Healthcare Professional: Yours? Doctor: The problem, well the worst thing is my son sent a picture to all of his friends and you know my sister; he sent it to his cousin, my sister’s kids and so they told my sister and I hadn’t had a chance to tell her that I bought this car. And she’s like, “Are you out of your mind? You bought N____ a Mercedes?” (Chuckles)

text: Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: - because up until this point we’ve been talking about you have an invisible cancer. Family Member: Uh hum. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: We know that it has recurred; we simply cannot see it or spot it or target that. Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: Um the reality is that we have tried that in the past and we still do that on occasion in certain patients. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: All the lymph nodes are connected to each other by so-called lymphatic system - Family Member: Uh hum. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: - and so the the the concern about targeting one particular lymph node or maybe two lymph nodes or three lymph nodes is is that um you might only be affecting you know ten percent, fifteen percent, thirty percent of the cancer cells in your body.

text: Patient: Yeah, yeah, yeah. Doctor: That’s one perspective, okay? Patient: Sure. Doctor: So the other thing, so we’ve got this fifty/fifty with the hormones and radiation. The question is what else can we do. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: So what else we can do is we can hit what’s remaining as far as the cancer really hard right now and when I say really hard what we’re talking about is some chemotherapy, um which we give you through the vein every three weeks and we give you four doses of it. It’s a medicine called Taxotere. And we add in um uh, if we can get insurance to pay for it, but generally we can; we add in a super-hormone medicine called ah Zytiga or Addaram. It’s a pill you take ah every day. It’s four pills every day. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: So that’s quite frankly that’s a, it’s a clinical trial we offer, but because of a stupid loophole which I didn’t realize I can’t put you on the clinical trial because you were on the other one. (Laughs) Patient: Right. Doctor: And uhm it’s a loophole I’m going to fix. Patient: Uh hum. Patient: Right.

text: Patient: Yeah. Doctor: -and it was two something before. So with that rise, I got a little worried. Because I don't want the Xtandi to get away from us. At that point, there was a study and there still is, where people on Xtandi if they start to do this with their PSA, might be eligible to add another pill right on to that. So you still stay on Xtandi. But this other pill might make the Xtandi sort of work better. And, you know, if you were on full dose, you'd be eligible, if you were on three pills, as well as just the two pills a day is still an option. So initially, we weren't sure if it was going to open because this was a study that had a sugar pill arm that I wasn't too keen on. But with this new, kind of like update, everybody gets the pill. So this is where the study is. So here you are in your Xtandi. Xtandi, Xtandi, Xtandi. And then you get randomized. So flip of a coin to either get this new medicine at a certain dose, or this new medicine at the same dose. Okay, so so far, both arms are the same, you just get a new medicine at the same dose, okay, no placebo. This arm is going to keep you like that, so you take the Xtandi plus the new pill at the new dose, no problem, you're just on that. This arm is you on Xtandi plus the new pill, but every month, they're going to try to increase that dose gently. So you get another pill that has more milligrams in it. While that's happening, if you were on this arm, you get a matching placebo. So you do get a sugar pill, but that's in addition to the new pill already being on board. You still with me? Patient: No, you gotta slow down. Doctor: Okay. Do you want me to say it again? Patient: Try me again. Doctor: Okay, no worries. Okay, here's you. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: “Hello, I’m Mr. P___ I'm on two of Xtandi”. Patient: Yes. Doctor: PSA is starting to do this, uh-oh, we're kind of worried. So, sometimes the cancer gets smart. And now we say look, maybe there's a way to kind of flap that, see if we can get it to work again, because it did work for a while, which was good. So this pill going right along, we want to add a second pill. Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: This study is to add a second pill, different pathway, to say hey, I'm gonna see if I add the second guy whether both together will make your PSA drop. But of course, to make things complicated, the second pill, they want to do stuff too. So they're going to have two groups. So if you're in the first group, you keep going on your Xtandi, and you get the second pill at a particular dose, no problem. Then W____ is on the same study, he's on Xtandi two pills a day. And I give him also the second pill at the same dose. Nobody's placebo-ing, you're now on two potentially active medicines, okay. But to make the study even more interesting, what they're doing is, if you are doing okay, on those two doses, they're going to give you an extra, you know, like 40 milligrams every month to see if they can increase that dose to get better mileage on this activity. But W____ is going to also get a matching pill. But his is not an active 40 milligrams, he just gets the sugar version of the 40 milligrams. Patient: Okay.

text: Patient: In group one. Doctor: I don’t know if it’s group one; I heard group two. Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: Um. text: Patient: So let me ask you this here, doc. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Do people come out of that surgery? Doctor: Oh, yeah! They do! (Cell phone rings) Patient: Right. Doctor: But it’s a start. So, what does that tell us? It’s aggressive, but we know that about your cancer. But, if we don’t talk about surgery as an option, then we didn’t do right by you because you know that that’s a possibility. What’s the root of all that? Well, it’s your cancer not controlled. That’s always the root of all evil. Not your bones, but your lymph nodes are growing. So, in this – Patient: So what’s goin’ on, so what’s goin’ on with my bones? Doctor: Nothin’. Patient: He just said that somethin’ was goin’ on with my bones. Healthcare Professional 1: No. I didn’t say anything. Patient: The other doctor that came in before him, before Dr. P_, said somethin’ was goin’ on with my bones. Healthcare Professional 1: Oh.

text: Patient: I am, totally. Doctor: I mean, that, you know? Patient: I’m having fun. Doctor: That’s a scale. I mean that’s amazing. Wow. When you’re talented, you’re talented. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: And there’s nothing like cancer that’s going to stop you. Family Member: No. Patient: No. It ain’t going to stop me. I’ve got to do what I’ve got to do. It ain’t going to stop me. I’ve got to be a superstar. It’s not going to stop me. Patient: Now that I’ll get you and we’ll shoot a video. Doctor: Oh. Patient: Video. Doctor: Oh, man. Yes! Let’s do it! You got to give me a heads up.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
